verses.verse: Then I returned <S%H7725><s%> and saw <S%H7200><s%> all the oppressions <S%H6217><s%> that are done <S%H6213><s%> under the sun <S%H8121><s%>: and <S%H1832><s%>, behold, the tears of such as were oppressed <S%H6231><s%>, and they had no comforter <S%H5162><s%>; and on the side <S%H3027><s%> of their oppressors <S%H6231><s%> there was power <S%H3581><s%>; but they had no comforter <S%H5162><s%>.
Wherefore I praised <S%H7623><s%> the dead <S%H4191><s%> that have been <S%H3528><s%> long dead <S%H4191><s%> more than the living <S%H2416><s%> that are yet <S%H5728><s%> alive <S%H2416><s%>;

yea <S%H2896><s%>, better than them both <S%H8147><s%> did I esteem him that hath not yet <S%H5728><s%> been <S%H7200><s%>, who hath not seen the evil <S%H7451><s%> work <S%H4639><s%> that is done <S%H6213><s%> under the sun <S%H8121><s%>.

Then I saw <S%H7200><s%> all labor <S%H5999><s%> and every skilful <S%H3788><s%> work <S%H4639><s%>, that for this a man <S%H376><s%> is envied <S%H7068><s%> of his neighbor <S%H7453><s%>. This also is vanity <S%H1892><s%> and a striving <S%H7469><s%> after wind <S%H7307><s%>.
The fool <S%H3684><s%> foldeth <S%H2263><s%> his hands <S%H3027><s%> together <S%H2263><s%>, and eateth <S%H398><s%> his own flesh <S%H1320><s%>.

Better <S%H2896><s%> is a handful <S%H3709><s%>, with quietness <S%H5183><s%>, than two <S%H2651><s%> handfuls <S%H4393><s%> with labor <S%H5999><s%> and striving <S%H7469><s%> after wind <S%H7307><s%>.
Then I returned <S%H7725><s%> and saw <S%H7200><s%> vanity <S%H1892><s%> under the sun <S%H8121><s%>.

There is <S%H3426><s%> one <S%H259><s%> that is alone <S%H8145><s%>, and he hath not a second; yea <S%H1121><s%>, he hath neither son nor brother <S%H251><s%>; yet is there no end <S%H7093><s%> of all his labor <S%H5999><s%>, neither are his eyes <S%H5869><s%> satisfied <S%H7646><s%> with riches <S%H6239><s%>. For whom then <S%H6001><s%>, saith he, do I labor, and deprive <S%H2637><s%> my soul <S%H5315><s%> of good <S%H2896><s%>? This also is vanity <S%H1892><s%>, yea <S%H7451><s%>, it is a sore travail <S%H6045><s%>.
Two <S%H8147><s%> are better <S%H2896><s%> than one <S%H259><s%>, because they have <S%H3426><s%> a good <S%H2896><s%> reward <S%H7939><s%> for their labor <S%H5999><s%>.

For if they fall <S%H5307><s%>, the one <S%H259><s%> will lift up <S%H6965><s%> his fellow <S%H2270><s%>; but woe <S%H337><s%> to him that is alone <S%H259><s%> when he falleth <S%H5307><s%>, and hath not another <S%H8145><s%> to lift him up <S%H6965><s%>.
Again <S%H1571><s%>, if two <S%H8147><s%> lie together <S%H7901><s%>, then they have warmth <S%H2552><s%>; but how can one <S%H259><s%> be warm alone <S%H3179><s%>?

And if a man <S%H259><s%> prevail <S%H8630><s%> against him that is alone <S%H8147><s%>, two shall withstand <S%H5975><s%> him <S%H8027><s%>; and a threefold cord <S%H2339><s%> is not quickly <S%H4120><s%> broken <S%H5423><s%>.

Better <S%H2896><s%> is a poor <S%H4542><s%> and wise <S%H2450><s%> youth <S%H3206><s%> than an old <S%H2205><s%> and foolish <S%H3684><s%> king <S%H4428><s%>, who knoweth <S%H3045><s%> not how to receive admonition any more <S%H2094><s%>.
For out of prison <S%H631><s%> he came <S%H3318><s%> forth to be king <S%H4427><s%>; yea <S%H4438><s%>, even in his kingdom he was born <S%H3205><s%> poor <S%H7326><s%>.

I saw <S%H7200><s%> all the living <S%H2416><s%> that walk <S%H1980><s%> under the sun <S%H8121><s%>, that they were with the youth <S%H3206><s%>, the second <S%H8145><s%>, that stood up in his stead <S%H5975><s%>.

There was no end <S%H7093><s%> of all the people <S%H5971><s%>, even of all them over whom he was <S%H6440><s%>: yet they that come after <S%H314><s%> shall not rejoice <S%H8055><s%> in him <S%H1892><s%>. Surely this also is vanity and a striving <S%H7475><s%> after wind <S%H7307><s%>.
